titleStmt.title: Particle swarm optimization with preference order ranking for multi-objective optimization

analytic.title: Particle swarm optimization with preference order ranking for multi-objective optimization

biblStruct.note: Received 22 February 2008 Received in revised form 16 December 2008 Accepted 3 January 2009 Information Sciences 179 (2009) 1944-1959

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

textClass.keywords: Particle swarm Preference order Pareto dominance Multi-objective optimization Best compromise

div.p: A new optimality criterion based on preference order (PO) scheme is used to identify the best compromise in multi-objective particle swarm optimization (MOPSO). This scheme is more efficient than Pareto ranking scheme, especially when the number of objectives is very large. Meanwhile, a novel updating formula for the particle's velocity is introduced to improve the search ability of the algorithm. The proposed algorithm has been compared with NSGA-II and other two MOPSO algorithms. The experimental results indicate that the proposed approach is effective on the highly complex multi-objective optimization problems.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: In the real world, there are many problems involving multiple objectives, which should be optimized simultaneously and are often incommensurable. Evolutionary algorithm (EA) is a class of stochastic optimization methods. It is especially suitable to solve multi-objective optimization problems (MOPs) because it can deal simultaneously with a set of possible solutions in a single run instead of a series of separate runs as in the traditional optimization techniques [22,3,8]. Many evolutionary multi-objective optimization algorithms have been developed in the last few years, such as swarm intelligence, evolutionary computation and artificial immune systems [29,25,30,26].

Particle swarm optimization (PSO) [15] is one form of swarm intelligence inspired by the behavior of bird flocks. It has been successfully used to solve single-objective optimization [16,10] because of its high convergence speed and relative simplicity. These motivate researchers to solve MOPs by using PSO [4]. In [24], Pareto dominance is used and the concepts of evolutionary techniques are combined with PSO. The method applied the crowding approach to maintain the diversity and handled constraints by a multilevel sieve. Li [19] incorporated the main mechanisms of NSGA-II [8] into PSO. In his algorithm, the population of the particles was combined with the personal best position, and the best was selected from this new population to compose the next population. In [13], an unconstrained elite archive interacted with the primary population is used to store the nondominated solutions and define the local best positions, moreover, the concept of the turbulence is also incorporated. In Coello et al.'s method [2], each particle deposited its flight experiences in a global repository. This repository was used by the particles to identify a leader that guided the search. A mutation operator was also adopted that acted on both the particles and each design variable of the problem to be solved. In [18], the fitness assigned to each individual in the archive was computed according to its density. By means of roulette wheel selection, this fitness was used to pick out the global best position, and further, the velocity of the particle was updated by this position. Liu et al. [20] proposed a hybrid PSO, which combined the global search ability of PSO with a synchronous local fine-tuning and used fuzzy global best to handle the premature convergence. In [30], the vital parameters in PSO, namely the inertia weight and the acceleration coefficients, were adaptive during the iterations. In [23], the the crowding distance was incorporated into PSO and the distribution of nondominated solutions was improved on the Pareto front.

The main difficulty in MOPSO is how to identify the global best in the population [1], because there is a set of compromise solutions in an MOP instead of one best solution in a single-objective problem. Most available MOPSO algorithms utilize the concept of Pareto dominance to classify the solutions. However, as shown theoretically in [12] and empirically evidenced in [6], the proportion of Pareto optimal solutions in a nondominated set grows with the number of objectives. Thus, MOPSO algorithms based on Pareto dominance ranking procedure become ineffective in sorting out the quality of solutions when the number of objectives increases.

Instead of Pareto dominance, preference order is used in this paper to alleviate the aforementioned lack of effectiveness. PO is a generalization of Pareto optimality that provides the definition of efficiency more stringent than Pareto dominance to compare the solutions in MOPs [5]. It can help to reduce the number of points in a nondomiated solution set by retaining only those regarded as the ''best compromise" [11], and then the ''best compromise" as a leader guides the population to the desirable optimal regions. In order to enhance the global search ability, a novel updating formula for the particle's velocity is introduced. A series of extensive experiments is performed on seven widely applied test functions [9], namely DTLZ1-7 from four to eight objectives, and the solutions are evaluated by a suite of performance metrics. The proposed algorithm is compared with NSGA-II and other two MOPSO algorithms, which are based on Pareto dominance ranking scheme. The experimental results confirm that the proposed algorithm achieves better performance of the convergence and the sufficient diversity.

The rest of the paper is organized as follows: Sections 2 and 3 briefly describe the concepts of MOP and the structure of PSO respectively. In Section 4, the details of the proposed algorithm are introduced. The formulae of seven test functions are given in Section 5, and three different metrics to evaluate the performances of an algorithm are also introduced. Experimental results and discussions are presented in Section 6. Finally, conclusions and future work are given in Section 7.

div.head: Multi-objective optimization and the notion of dominance
div.p: Assuming minimizing m objectives, a multi-objective optimization problem can be described as follows: min y ¼ fðxÞ ¼ ðf 1 ðxÞ; f 2 ðxÞ; . . . ; f m ðxÞÞ; where x ¼ ðx 1 ; . . . ; x n Þ 2 X is an n-dimensional decision variable vector and X is the decision variable space; y ¼ ðy 1 ; . . . ; y m Þ 2 Y is an m-dimensional objective vector and Y is the objective space.

A decision vector u 2 X is said to strictly dominate another decision vector v 2 X, denoted by u 0 v, if and only if (iff) 8i 2 f1; . . . ; mg : f i ðuÞ 6 f i ðvÞ and 9j 2 f1; . . . ; mg : f j ðuÞ < f j ðvÞ.

A decision vector x 2 X is said to be Pareto optimal with respect to X iff there is no other decision vector that dominates x in X. The set of all Pareto optimal solutions in the decision variable space is called Pareto optimal set and the corresponding set of objective vector is called Pareto optimal front.

div.head: Particle swarm optimization
div.p: PSO is inspired by the social behavior of animals [15]. Each particle has a position x ¼ ðx 1 ; x 2 ; . . . ; x D Þ and a velocity v ¼ ðv 1 ; v 2 ; . . . ; v D Þ in a variable space. In generation t þ 1, the velocity and the position are updated as follows:
div.formula: v tþ1 id ¼ xv t id þ c 1 r 1 ðp t id À x t id Þ þ c 2 r 2 ðp t gd À x t id Þ;ð1Þ
x tþ1 id ¼ x t id þ v tþ1 id ;ð2Þ
div.p: where i ¼ 1; . . . ; N and N is the population size; d ¼ 1; . . . ; D and D is the dimension of search space; x is the inertia weight; c 1 and c 2 are two positive constants; r 1 and r 2 are random values in the range [0, 1]; p t id is the personal best of the particle i in generation t; p t gd is the global best of population in generation t. The performance of each particle is evaluated according to a pre-defined fitness function, which is related to the problem concerned.

div.head: Multi-objective particle swarm optimization with preference order
div.p: In MOPSO, the velocity of the particle is modified to fly towards the personal best and the global best. To identify the global best, the most straightforward approach is to consider every nondominated solution as a new leader. However, the drawback of this method is the size of nondominated set becomes very large with the number of objectives increasing. An intuitionistic explanation is suggested by Fig. 1. Suppose that there exists a point f 0 in the objective space. Pareto dominance induces a partition onto the objective space, where points that dominate f 0 and that are dominated by f 0 , are denoted by F þ f 0 and F À f 0 respectively. Moving from a two-dimensional to a three-dimensional objective space, the number of points nondominated by f 0 grows from a plane to a cube. To increase the selective pressure, the identification quality to these nondominated solutions becomes critical in MOPSO.

div.head: The concept of PO
div.p: Preference order [5] is a generalization of Pareto optimality. It provides a way to designate some Pareto solutions superior to others when the size of the nondominated solution set is very large. Definition 1. A point x Ã 2 X is considered efficiency of order k if fðx Ã Þ is not dominated by any of the k-element subsets of f X , where X is the feasible region for an MOP and f X is the image of the feasible region in the objective space.
div.formula: Claim 1. If x Ã is efficiency of order k, then it is efficiency of order k þ 1.
div.p: This claim has been proven by Das [5]. It is clear that efficiency of order m is the ordinary concept of Pareto optimality, hence efficiency of order k is an extension of Pareto optimality.

Efficiency of order can be used to reduce the number of points in a nondominated set by retaining only those regarded as the ''best compromise" [11]. In order to explain the ''best compromise", consider a Pareto point P which has a near-minimum value for one objective but fairly high values for all the rest. Such a point lies at an extreme end of the Pareto surface and is not considered as a good compromise among all objectives. The point P is not qualified when the efficiency of order is m À 1, because it is not presented in one of the ðm À 1Þ-element subsets of the objectives. For this subset, P is unlikely to be a Pareto optimal solution since it is dominated by other points in the subset. Therefore, it is concluded that the fewer extreme components a point has, the more likely it is to be efficiency of order.

div.head: Particle swarm optimization with preference order ranking procedure
div.p: This subsection describes the proposed MOPSO algorithm with preference order ranking procedure. Firstly, PO ranking procedure is introduced, then the details of the proposed algorithm are given.

In this study, the positions of Pareto nondominated particles are stored in the external archive. To find the ''best compromise", the nondominated solutions are ranked according to PO. The ranking procedure can be summarized below:
(1) Identify the combinations of all subsets to m objectives;
(2) Assign the order to all nondominated solutions for each combination of all subsets based on PO;
(3) Identify the ''best compromise" in all nondominated solutions according to their order.

A simple example is given to illustrate PO ranking procedure, and the set of nondominated vectors in R 3 is shown in Table 1. Firstly, identify the combinations of all subsets, namely ff 1 ; f 2 ; f 3 ; ðf 1 ; f 2 Þ; ðf 1 ; f 3 Þ; ðf 2 ; f 3 Þg. Then assign the order to each point for all subsets. The dominance relation of all points in 2-element subsets is shown in Table 2. The symbol ''Â" represents the nondominated relationship. On the ðf 1 ; f 2 Þ subset, point 2 is dominated by point 3 and 5; on the ðf 1 ; f 3 Þ subset, point 1 is On the basis of the above ranking procedure, the steps of the proposed algorithm are summarized as follows.
div.formula: I 1 I 2 ' f + ' f ' f I 2 I 2 ' + ' f ' f f I 3 I 1
div.p: (1) Initialization.

The population size, the archive size and the maximum number of iterations are initialized according to the problem concerned. The velocities and the positions are initialized randomly. The initial value of the personal best for each particle is equal to its initial position. (2) Update the velocities and the positions.

In order to control the balance of global and local search, a new updating equation for the velocity is adopted. Two parameters, namely r 1 and r 2 in Eq. ( 1), are independently and randomly generated, so there are cases in which two random parameters are both too large or too small. In the former case, both the personal and the social experiences accumulated so far are over used, and result in that the particles are driven too far away from the local optimum. For the latter case, both the personal and the social experiences are not used fully, and the convergence speed of the algorithm is reduced. In the proposed algorithm the velocity is updated as follows:
div.formula: v tþ1 id ¼ x tþ1 v t id þ ð1 À r 2 Þc 1 r 1 ðp t id À x t id Þ þ ð1 À r 2 Þc 2 ð1 À r 1 Þðp t gd À x t id Þ:ð3Þ
div.p: The inertia weight x tþ1 in Eq. ( 3) is adjusted dynamically as follows:
div.formula: x tþ1 ¼ x t f x ;ð4Þ
div.p: where f x is a constant between 0 and 1.For the personal best, it is easily defined by the concept of domination. But it is difficult to define the global best because there is a set of compromise solutions in MOPs. In order to identify the best compromise, the PO scheme is used to classify the solutions in this study. Neither the crowding distance [8] nor the density parameter [30] is needed to be computed. The superior solutions in the nondominated set are identified via PO scheme mentioned above. Then the best compromise is used as the global best to update the velocity according to Eq.
After updating the velocities of the particles, the positions are updated by Eq. ( 2).

Table 2 The dominance relation for all points in 2-element subsets. (c) initialize p 0 id for each particle, p 0 id x 0 id . (d) initialize archive, A 0 S 0 . / * S 0 : the nondominated solutions in the population * / (2) for t ¼ 1 to tmax (a) Use PO scheme to identify the best compromise (i) get combination. / * returns the combination of all subsets for m objectives * / (ii) get efficiency order.
div.formula: Point 1 Point 2 Point 3 Point 4 Point 5 Point 1 Â Â Â Â Â Point 2 ðf 2 ; f 3 Þ Â Â ð f 2 ; f 3 Þ Â Point 3 ðf 2 ; f 3 Þ ð f 1 ; f 2 Þ Â ð f 2 ; f 3 Þ ð f 1 ; f 3 Þ Point 4 ðf 1 ; f 3 Þ Â Â Â ð f 1 ; f 3 Þ Point 5 ðf 2 ; f 3 Þ ð f 1 ; f 2 Þ Â Â Â
div.p: / * compute the efficiency order for each nondominated solution from the archive on each subset * / (iii) sort nondominated solutions.

/ * sort nondominated solutions in descending order according to their efficiency order * / (iv) get p t gd . / * the solution with maximum efficiency order is defined as global best * / (b) update velocity of each particle according to the Eq. ( 3). (c) update position of each particle according to the Eq. ( 2). (d) update p t id of each particle.
(e) update xt according to the Eq. ( 4).
(f) update archive. / * if the archive size Na is exceeded, the solutions with lower efficiency order are deleted from the end of archive * / (3) end (3) Update archive.

In each generation, the archive is updated by the nondominated solutions from the population. If the archive size exceeds the maximum size, the solutions in the archive are sorted in descending order according to their efficiency order. The solutions with lower efficiency order are deleted from the end of the archive. (4) Termination.
The algorithm is terminated if it reaches the maximum number of iterations. The final nondominated solutions are contained in the external archive.
Based on the above discussions, the pseudocode of the proposed algorithm is given in Table 3.

div.head: Parameters selection
div.p: The population size, the external archive size and the maximum number of iterations are set according to the problem concerned. It has been shown experimentally in [6] that the proportion of nondominated solutions decreases with the population size increasing. Therefore, the population size is usually set from 30 to 100. The external archive size is equal to the population size.

The range of the inertia weight is from 0.7 to 1.4, which can achieve better trade-off between the global and the local exploration abilities [28]. The parameters c 1 and c 2 are usually equal to 2 [21]. In this paper, more trust is considered in the group than in the individual particle, so c 1 and c 2 are set as 1.5 and 2.5, respectively.
All parameters and their range of the values used in this study are summarized in Table 4. For other optimal problems, the configurations of the parameters depend on the problem at hand.

div.head: Test functions
div.p: In order to compare the performance with other MOPSO algorithms, seven well-known test functions are chosen, namely DTLZ1-7, which can test the different abilities of an algorithm [11,9]. These test functions have some important features as follows:
(1) the relatively small implementation effort (bottom-up approach and constraint surface approach);
(2) they can be scaled to any number of objectives and decision variables;
(3) the global Pareto front is known analytically; (4) convergence and diversity difficulties can be easily controlled.

The mathematical formulations of the test functions DTLZ1-7 along with their decision space and the optimal solutions are presented in Table 5. n and m are the number of decision variables and objective functions respectively. M is the difficulty factor which is equal to n À m þ 1. This study focuses the analysis on four to eight objectives, i.e., m ¼ 4; 5; 6; 7 and 8. The parameter a is suggested as 100 for DTLZ4 [9].

div.head: Performance metrics
div.p: Generational Distance (GD): The concept of generational distance [31] is used to estimate how far the elements in the set of nondominated solutions are from those in the Pareto optimal set. The Pareto surfaces of the test functions DTLZ1-5 are easily expressed analytically, and therefore GD is computed as the expected value of the distance between each individual in a population and the Pareto surface. In contrast, the Pareto surfaces of DTLZ6 and DTLZ7 can not be represented with a simple formula [7]. Consequently, the GD metric for these test functions is computed as the expected value of the minimum distance between a point and a reference set, with respect to the entire population, as suggested in [4]:
div.formula: GD , E N X N i¼1 d 2 i ! 1=2 2 4 3 5 : Table 4
div.p: Parameters and their range of values are used in the proposed algorithm.

div.head: Parameter
div.p: The range of value
The population size N [30, 100] The external archive size Na
The range of the inertia weight x
Table 5 Description of the test functions are used in this study.

X ¼ fxj0
SP ¼ ffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffi 1 n À 1 X n i¼1 ð d À d i Þ 2 v u u t ;
div.p: where d i ¼ min j P m k¼1 jf i m À f j m j ; i; j ¼ 1; . . . ; n and n is the number of the nondominated solutions generated by the algorithm; m is the number of objectives;
d is the mean of all d i . A value of zero for this measure indicates that all the nondominated solutions found are equidistantly spaced.

Diversity Metric 1 (DM1) and 2 (DM2): These metrics [7] are introduced to measure the diversity of the solutions with respect to a reference set (RS). The obtained nondominated points are projected on a suitable hyperplane, thereby losing one dimension of the points. The plane is divided into a number of small grids. A diversity metric is defined depending on whether each grid contains an obtained nondominated point or not. If all grids are represented with at least one point, the best possible (with respect to the chosen number of grids) diversity measure is achieved. If some grids are not represented by a nondominated point, the diversity is poor. The reference of plane, the number of grids and the reference set of points P Ã are set by the user. The details of the diversity metric computation are given below:

(1) For each grid indexed by ði; j; . . .Þ, calculate the following two arrays: Hði; j; . . . (2) Assign a value mðhði; j; . . .ÞÞ to each grid depending on its and its neighbor's hðÁÞ. Similarly, calculate mðHði; j; . . .ÞÞ using HðÁÞ for the reference points. (3) Calculate the diversity metric as follows: DM ¼ P i;j;... Hði;j;...Þ-0 mðhði; j; . . .ÞÞ P i;j;... Hði;j;...Þ-0 mðHði; j; . . .ÞÞ :
In [7,17], the authors suggested a neighboring scheme to compute the values of mðhÞ and mðHÞ. The same scheme is used in this study presented in Table 6.

Ideally all nondominated solutions generated by the algorithm are on the global Pareto optimal front. In such a condition, the diversity metric is called DM1 [17]. But if the algorithm can not converge to the global Pareto optimal front, DM1 can not measure the diversity of nondominated solutions. In that case, the diversity metric is calculated based on the actual converged front, and this diversity metric is called DM2. Comparing the diversity of two algorithms, DM2 is preferred because even if one algorithm has converged to true Pareto optimal front while the other has not, DM2 of the former will be almost equal to its DM1 value.

div.head: Experimental results and discussion
div.p: In this section, the proposed algorithm is compared with other three algorithms, i.e., MOPSO [2], MOPSO-CD [23] and NSGA-II [8], which are based on Pareto ranking scheme. All these algorithms are evaluated using the same test functions.
The details of the parameters used in this study are given below according to Section 4.3:
Both the population size and the archive size are set as 80.

The number of runs, the maximum number of iterations and difficulty factor M for seven test functions are shown in Table 7. c 1 and c 2 are suggested as 1.5 and 2.5 [14], respectively. The initial value of the inertia weight is set to 1.4 and the constant f x is equal to 0.975. The parameters of MOPSO are set to the default values as suggested in [2], which are given as follows:
The mutation rate is set to 0.5. The number of adaptive grids is set to 30.
The value of the inertia weight is 0.4.

The values of the parameters for MOPSO-CD are same as MOPSO as suggested in [23]. The parameters of NSGA-II are set as suggested in [8], i.e., the crossover probability of 0.9 and the mutation probability of 1=N. In order to make the number of fitness function evaluations the same, the population size and the maximum number of iterations for all algorithms are set the same as the proposed algorithm.
To compute the diversity metrics DM1 and DM2, the number of the points in the reference set, the lesser dimensional reference plane and the number of grids are specified in Table 8.

The numerical values of mean and standard deviation GD are shown in Table 9, together with the formula to compute GD for each test function. At the same time, the trend of mean values of GD versus the number of objectives is shown in Fig. 2 for all algorithms. Clearly that almost all results based on PSO are better than NSGA-II for all test functions as demonstrated in Table 9. The values of GD indicate that the convergence of the proposed algorithm is better than the other two PSO algorithms. The results of DTLZ1 and DTLZ3 generated by the proposed algorithm are more remarkable than MOPSO and MOPSO-CD, especially when the number of objectives is 6, 7, and 8. As suggested in [9], DTLZ3 is suitable to test the search ability of an algorithm because it introduces many local Pareto fronts. So it can be concluded that the convergence property of the proposed algorithm is better than those algorithms based on Pareto dominance scheme with the number of objectives increasing.

Table 10 shows the mean and standard deviation values of SP for four algorithms on seven test functions with the number of objectives from four to eight. It can be seen from Table 10 that the proposed algorithm obtains better distribution for all test functions. In order to investigate the ability of an algorithm to maintain a good distribution on the final nondominated front, the test function DTLZ4 is considered because it generates a nonuniform distribution of the points along the Pareto optimal front [9]. When the number of objectives is from five to eight for DTLZ4, the results of the proposed algorithm outperform MOPSO and MOPSO-CD. The main reason is that our algorithm can identify the ''best compromise" to search wider space in the case that the number of objectives is very large. The trend of mean values of SP versus the number of objectives is shown in Fig. 3 for all algorithms. The mean and standard deviation values of DM1 and DM2 are shown in Tables 11 and12 respectively. From Table 11, it can be seen that the results of the proposed algorithm are better than the other three algorithms for all test functions. For DM2 shown in Table 12, the algorithms based on PSO techniques, i.e., MOPSO, MOPSO-CD and the proposed algorithm, are worse than NSGA-II when the number of objectives is four. However, the results of our algorithm are better than all the other three algorithms when the number of objectives is from five to eight. The DM2 values of MOPSO and MOPSO-CD are also worse than NSGA-II with the number of objectives increasing. Thus, the advantage of the proposed algorithm is obvious compared with the other two Pareto-based MOPSO algorithms. Therefore, it can be concluded that our algorithm produces the better diversity performance than the other three algorithms in the case that the number of objectives is large. The trend of mean values of DM1 and DM2 versus the number of objectives is shown in Fig. 4 for all algorithms.

It can be seen from the above results, that our approach rewards the individuals whose solutions have better quality. The analysis of the GD values indicates that the proposed algorithm achieves better convergence property than the other three algorithms when the number of objectives is five or more. In addition, the values of SP and diversity metrics suggest that our algorithm is more effective in maintaining a set of well spread solutions over the Pareto surface.

div.head: Conclusion
div.p: A new MOPSO algorithm has been presented, where the PO scheme is used instead of the Pareto dominance. It can be seen from the experimental results that the proposed algorithm improves the exploratory ability of MOPSO by means of searching the ''best compromise". Experimental results confirm that the proposed algorithm attains better convergence to the true Pareto surface for all test functions, and the performance gap shows a remarkable increasing trend when the number of objectives is large. At the same time, the proposed algorithm is more effective in maintaining the diversity of the solutions. The main aspect to be explored in the future is to extend the proposed algorithm to handle the real world multi-objective problems. In this case, more details and parameters should be considered.
